text:
Thank you for all your contributions, I will feature 8-10 of these in my post along with your comments on why you love them.

Kindly drop your Full names, what you do, and where you'd love me to link it to. Also, I'd add your headshots you have here on Slack along with your comments.

Thank you.

text:
Hello friends, I’ve been working on a project for almost a year now and it’s ready to ship soon. With the recent crisis, it feels weird to be announcing a project. I’ve had to rewrite the entire launch promo. I’m struggling with balancing an optimistic tone that acknowledges the crisis and hard times people are going through + talking about the new platform we’re launching.

I almost feel like I can’t just jump into the promo of the launch without acknowledging what’s happening in the world.

I’ve noticed a lot of tone-deaf emails from companies and CEOs. It’s jarring.

Has anyone seen good examples (tone, framing, etc.) with companies that recently in the last 3-5 weeks launched a new endeavor?  Would love some inspiring examples to read and learn from. Thank you, and hope you’re all well!

elements.text:

I’ve had to rewrite the entire launch promo. I’m struggling with balancing an optimistic tone that acknowledges the crisis and hard times people are going through + talking about the new platform we’re launching.

I almost feel like I can’t just jump into the promo of the launch without acknowledging what’s happening in the world.

I’ve noticed a lot of tone-deaf emails from companies and CEOs. It’s jarring.

Has anyone seen good examples (tone, framing, etc.) with companies that recently in the last 3-5 weeks launched a new endeavor?  Would love some inspiring examples to read and learn from. Thank you, and hope you’re all well!

text: may I ask what the project is? That might color the approach

elements.text: may I ask what the project is? That might color the approach

text: in any case, good on you for thinking about it. That’s more than some already

elements.text: in any case, good on you for thinking about it. That’s more than some already

text: I work at a design company. The project is a new editorial platform where we share stories on what we do and how we do it. Many students/creative people have asked us to talk more about our process and philosophy on design and creativity.

elements.text: I work at a design company. The project is a new editorial platform where we share stories on what we do and how we do it. Many students/creative people have asked us to talk more about our process and philosophy on design and creativity.

text: I’d frame the messaging around community. I know that’s a little vague but I think that’s something we all desire right now.

elements.text: I’d frame the messaging around community. I know that’s a little vague but I think that’s something we all desire right now.

text:
I am a big fan of SuperHi and they launched new projects for April. The full write-up of the announcement is here: <https://www.notion.so/SuperHi-April-2020-Announcement-c4e8470d87044b98a9cb21c3e8b3e00d>

You can check out their social media channel to see how they frame it in a more cold setting.

attachments.title: SuperHi April 2020 Announcement
attachments.fallback: SuperHi on Notion: SuperHi April 2020 Announcement

elements.text: I am a big fan of SuperHi and they launched new projects for April. The full write-up of the announcement is here:
You can check out their social media channel to see how they frame it in a more cold setting.

text: I think the key is to keep it simple – we all know what’s going on so there’s no need to talk too much about “the situation” (unless your project hits at specific problems caused/related to the pandemic). I also like SuperHi’s tone because it manages to be light and positive, without being tone-deaf.

I also like SuperHi’s tone because it manages to be light and positive, without being tone-deaf.

text:
I strongly agree with <@UJFELLXSR>, who recommended the work of Joana Wiebe at Copyhackers. I've bought almost everything she offers, and it's all great.

_For Letting Go of the Words_ by Ginny Reddish, be sure to get the most recent edition.

These are also worth reading:
_Web Copy That Sells_ by Maria Veloso
_Writing for the Web_ by Crawford Kilian
_Killer Web Content_ by Gerry McGovern
_Persuasive Online Copywriting_ by Bryan Eisenberg, Jeffrey Eisenberg, and Lisa T. Davis
_The Yahoo Style Guide_

text: Personally, I think the focus should be on your ideal customer regardless. Focus on how this tool will help them—during this time and beyond. People are online a lot right now, looking for resources, inspiration, how-to, and ESCAPE from the gloom. Some designers are losing jobs, on furlough, or struggling—think about how you can focus your language on *helping* them with resources, design inspo, furthering their domain knowledge, etc. If you want to discuss more, please feel free to DM me. But that's how I would think about it: focus on your audience, helping/inspiring that customer to be the best designer they can possibly be.

text:
<@UUVRX9C13> Let's not overlook the "mother of all B2B SaaS content marketing firms," HubSpot. They have two daily blogs, and their content is consistently great.

Have you thought about distinguishing between B2B SaaS companies that sell transactional solutions (low cost, low value, low complexity) versus SaaS companies that sell to enterprises (higher cost, higher value, higher complexity, and more complex buyer decisions)?

I would find that very interesting.

text:
<@UUVC2BFEY> This can be a sound strategy, provided you think it through carefully.

I suggest you forget about "industry standards" and give this careful thought for your own situation.

First, I suggest you calculate your current average cost per lead. This will tell you how much you currently pay to generate a lead across all channels.

Next, I suggest you calculate your average customer lifetime value (LTV). This will tell you how much money you make from each customer you acquire.

Then I suggest you differentiate among different kinds of referrals. Is it just a name with contact information?

Is it a prospect that fits your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)?

How well qualified is the referral? How close are they to buying, and how much sales and marketing effort must you put into converting them?

All of these factors will tell you how much you can afford to pay to get referrals.

For unqualified referrals, you can safely spend as much as currently spend to generate your own leads. Maybe more. This might be a flat fee that's close to your current cost per lead.

For qualified referrals that require little sales involvement and eventually turn into revenue, you can spend a lot more.

If you're in a recurring-revenue or subscription-based business, you must be clear with your referring partners about the base amount for which you'll pay commissions.

Will you pay a percentage of the total value of the deal under contract? (In other words, if they sign a deal for several years of annually recurring revenue, will you pay a commission on the full contract amount?) Or will you based your commission rate on only the on the year's revenue?

Working these details out in advance will protect relationships with valued referring partners, and they'll prevent you from paying too much.

elements.text:
This can be a sound strategy, provided you think it through carefully.

I suggest you forget about "industry standards" and give this careful thought for your own situation.

First, I suggest you calculate your current average cost per lead. This will tell you how much you currently pay to generate a lead across all channels.

Next, I suggest you calculate your average customer lifetime value (LTV). This will tell you how much money you make from each customer you acquire.

Then I suggest you differentiate among different kinds of referrals. Is it just a name with contact information?

Is it a prospect that fits your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)?

How well qualified is the referral? How close are they to buying, and how much sales and marketing effort must you put into converting them?

All of these factors will tell you how much you can afford to pay to get referrals.

For unqualified referrals, you can safely spend as much as currently spend to generate your own leads. Maybe more. This might be a flat fee that's close to your current cost per lead.

For qualified referrals that require little sales involvement and eventually turn into revenue, you can spend a lot more.

If you're in a recurring-revenue or subscription-based business, you must be clear with your referring partners about the base amount for which you'll pay commissions.

Will you pay a percentage of the total value of the deal under contract? (In other words, if they sign a deal for several years of annually recurring revenue, will you pay a commission on the full contract amount?) Or will you based your commission rate on only the on the year's revenue?

Working these details out in advance will protect relationships with valued referring partners, and they'll prevent you from paying too much.

text:
I like Ann Handley's book _Everybody Writes_. I think it's suitable for people who are not hard-core writers.

I also like the online tool <https://prowritingaid.com/|ProWriting Aid>, which I think is better than Grammarly.

attachments.title: ProWritingAid - the best grammar checker, style editor, and editing tool in one package.
attachments.text: Your personal writing coach. A grammar checker, style editor, and writing mentor in one package. The best writing depends on much more than just correct grammar. You need an editing tool that also highlights style issues and compares your writing to the best writers in your genre.
attachments.fallback: ProWritingAid - the best grammar checker, style editor, and editing tool in one package.

text: Hi friends! This may fall a bit outside the traditional content scope but I have a question about “content partnerships” for everyone:

elements.text: Hi friends! This may fall a bit outside the traditional content scope but I have a question about “content partnerships” for everyone:

text: A small startup CPG brand I’m helping out gets lots of inbound from affiliate marketing and paid influencer marketing type agencies. We would love to work with a GOOD, well respected one, but I suspect many of these are more like spam. We’re looking for someone who could help get the product into the hands of relevant influencer/health/lifestyle bloggers to do reviews, so sort of like micro PR and partnerships. Any recommendations for a good sponsored content or micro-influencer marketing platform or agency?

<@UV1T488RJ> I have a connection that does exactly what you're looking for. They're also the organizer of Advanced Search Summit and he's also in a mutual networking group.

While I haven't used influencer marketing myself, I've been to their events and have chatted with them a bit, so I'm pretty confident they're legitimate.

Feel free to DM me your email and a link to your site and I can make an intro.
